column2: Conditions related to abnormal structure, function, and integrity of the uteroplacental interface and maternal vascular supply.
column3: Histologic lesions indicative of abnormal maternal arterial remodeling and/or inadequate extravillous trophoblast differentiation and function.
column4: Failure of extravillous trophoblast to adequately invade the myometrium and remodel the spiral arteries.
column5: Persistence of vascular smooth muscle (or acute atherosis) in any medium-large artery in the basal plate of a non-marginal section from a delivered placenta at more than 24 weeks
column6: The presence of increased placental site giant cells within the superficial decidua (basal plate) of the delivered placenta, particularly when accompanied by significant amounts of adjacent decidua devoid of extravillous trophoblast
column7: Pathologic alterations affecting small to medium sized arteries and arterioles including muscular hypertrophy, endothelial/ vascular smooth muscle degeneration, fibrinoid necrosis, and mural infiltration by lipid laden macrophages (foam cells) - sometimes accompanied by surrounding chronic inflammation (perivasculitis); most frequently observed in the marginal decidua at the junction of the placental disc and membranes.
column8: Isolated concentric thickening of the arteriolar wall (lumen occupies less than 30% of diameter) due to a combination of medial and/or myointimal hyperplasia, hypertrophy, and extracellular matrix deposition.  No endothelial or myocyte injury.
column9: Mural hypertrophy with early degenerative changes including enlargement and detachment of endothelial cells, myocyte fragmentation, and/or a chronic perivascular mononuclear cell infiltrate.  Some vessels may show incipient fibrinoid necrosis.
column10: Fibrinoid necrosis (red-blue glassy degeneration of the arterial smooth muscle cells) and intramural lipid laden macrophages (foam cells).  Either finding may also be diagnosed separately
column11: Abnormal placental adherence to the uterine wall manifest as myometrium in the delivered placenta or absence of decidua between anchoring villi and myometrium
column12: Myometrial smooth muscle cells in the basal plate of a delivered placenta without placenta accreta.  Removal of an intact leiomyoma with the placenta (intraplacental leiomyoma) represents a subset of this condition.
column13: Anchoring villi directly implanted on myometrium without intervening gestational endometrium (decidua) - intervening fibrinoid matrix is allowed.
column14: Villi without intervening endometrium invading the myometrium beyond the normal endometrial-myometrial junction but not reaching the uterine serosa (excluding extension into space created by dehiscence of a previous C-section scar).
column15: Villi without intervening endometrium invading the myometrium beyond the normal endometrial-myometrial junction and extending to or beyond the uterine serosa (excluding extension into space created by dehiscence of a previous C-section scar).
column16: A form of ectopic pregnancy involving placental implantation at a previous C-section scar site including pregnancies extending through a scar dehiscence (isthmocele).
column17: Aggregates of incompletely differentiated, phenotypically immature (transitional) extravillous trophoblast, often with central cystic degeneration.  Lesions are separated by site: intraplacental-type (trophoblast islands and chorionic cysts), membranous-type (chorionic microcysts), and basal plate-type (excessive immature extravillous trophoblast with microcysts adjacent to anchoring villi).
column18: Trophoblast islands are aggregates of intraplacental-type immature (transitional) extravillous trophoblast (X-cells) within the parenchyma, often abutting large stem villi.  They are generally associated with large amounts of extracellular matrix type fibrinoid.  Trophoblast islands commonly undergo cystic degeneration to form chorionic cysts.  The finding of more than five trophoblast islands and/or chorionic cysts per slide is considered abnormal.
column19: Trophoblast islands with central cystic degeneration are chorionic cysts.  The finding of more than five trophoblast islands and/or chorionic cysts per slide is considered abnormal.
column20: Chorionic microcysts are small, usually 0.2-1 mm, cysts arising within an abnormally thick (more than 7 cell layers) area of membranous-type extravillous trophoblast in placental membranes.  More than 3 microcysts per membrane roll is considered abnormal.  Less commonly seen are basal plate microcysts, a feature associated with excessive basal plate type- immature (transitional) extravillous trophoblast in placentas with superficial implantation.
column21: Global accelerated villous maturation and/or distal villous hypoplasia or localized (segmental) tissue infarction (villous infarct) suggesting underlying decidual arteriopathy.
column22: Generalized abnormality in intervillous blood flow due to decidual arteriopathy resulting in accelerated villous maturation progressing in some cases to localized or diffuse underdevelopment of villous trees (distal villous hypoplasia)
column23: Accelerated villous maturation encompasses microscopic findings in the lower 2/3 of the placental parenchyma that are in excess of what is expected for gestational age; includes alternating areas of villous undergrowth and paucity (less extensive than distal villous hypoplasia) and areas of villous crowding with increased syncytial knots, intervillous fibrin deposition, and/or villous agglutination.
column24: The mean diameter and degree of branching of > 30% of distal villi is diffusely decreased in only one section (taken from the lower 2/3 of the midportion of the placenta).  The number of distal villi is reduced relative to the number of stem villi.  Focal areas may show villous crowding, agglutination, and “wave-like” syncytial knots.
column25: The mean diameter and degree of branching of > 30% of distal villi is diffusely decreased in more than one section (taken from the lower 2/3 of the midportion of the placenta).  The number of distal villi is reduced relative to the number of stem villi.  Focal areas may show villous crowding, agglutination, and “wave-like” syncytial knots.
column26: Firm lesions, granular on cut section, with a broad base abutting the maternal surface showing collapse of the intervillous space with agglutination of villi.
column27: Recent infarcts are firm lesions, red in color, with a broad base abutting the maternal surface.  Histologically, they show collapse of the intervillous space with agglutination of villi.  Variable amounts of karyorrhectic debris, neutrophils, and fibrin surround the collapsed villi. The villous trophoblast loses nuclear basophilia and the villous stroma retains its fetal vascular architecture with some mild degenerative changes.
column28: Remote infarcts are firm lesions, yellow in color, with a broad base abutting the maternal surface.  Histologically they show collapse of the intervillous space with agglutination of villi.  Foci of karyorrhectic debris and neutrophils persist around collapsed villi.  Large fetal stem villous vessels become obliterated, villous stroma is fibrotic, and there is loss of villous trophoblast and small fetal vessels.
column29: Premature separation of the placenta from the underlying uterus at the basal plate with accompanying retroplacental hemorrhage after 20 weeks and prior to birth
column30: Acute spiral artery rupture (<6 hours duration) with retroplacental hemorrhage causing premature separation of the placenta from the underlying uterus at the basal plate.
column31: Subacute spiral artery rupture (6-72 hours duration) with retroplacental hemorrhage causing premature separation of the placenta from the underlying uterus at the basal plate.
column32: Acute decidual venous rupture and hemorrhage at the placental margin causing premature separation of the placenta from the underlying uterus.
column33: Chronic decidual venous rupture (72 hours to 6 months) and hemorrhage at the placental margin causes a partial separation of the placenta from the underlying uterus without subsequent delivery.  Manifest histologically by organizing marginal hematomas, circumvallate membrane insertion, and adjacent hemosiderin laden macrophages.  Rupture into the amniotic cavity leads to diffuse chorioamnionic hemosiderosis
column34: Pathologic findings apparently related to abnormal maternal uteroplacental and/or intervillous blood flow, but with pathogenesis that is incompletely understood or controversial
column35: Circumferential accumulation of fibrinoid material - fibrin-type, matrix-type or both – around a portion or portions of the distal villous tree.
column36: Well circumscribed focus or multiple discrete foci of villi surrounded by perivillous fibrin without associated collapse of the intervillous space or acute trophoblast necrosis.
column37: Circumferential accumulation of fibrinoid material - fibrin-type, matrix-type or both – around a substantial percentage of distal villous tree, often basally centered, with accompanying secondary villous degenerative changes.
column38: Accumulations of fresh or clotted blood within the intervillous space that differ from classic intervillous thrombi.
column39: Rounded accumulation of fresh or clotted maternal blood surrounded by a rim of compressed, usually infarcted villi at least 5 villi in diameter; often multiple and accompanied by classic villous infarcts.
column40: Large aggregate of clotted blood located just below and grossly elevating the chorionic plate; often occupies a large percentage of the parenchymal volume in a preterm placenta
column41: Small accumulation of fresh or clotted blood within the intervillous space directly underlying the chorionic plate (i.e. not completely surrounded by distal villi as in classic intervillous thrombus/Kline’s hemorrhage).  Intermediate lesion exceeding normal subchorionic fibrin but not as extensive as massive subchorial thrombohematoma (significance unclear)
column42: Small accumulation of fresh or clotted blood within the intervillous space directly abutting the basal plate (i.e. not completely surrounded by distal villi as in classic intervillous thrombus/Kline’s hemorrhage).
column43: Pale plaque-like lesion in the intervillous space abutting the basal plate composed of spindle cells in a loose myxoid-appearing stroma.  May form following basal intervillous thrombus with replacement by myofibroblasts from decidua basalis.
column44: Conditions affecting the non-trophoblastic fetal components of the placenta, specifically the chorioallantoic mesenchyme, vasculature, and resident tissue macrophages.
column45: Variations from normal structure and composition of umbilical cord, chorionic plate, and villous trees
column46: Excessive numbers of fetal capillaries and venules relative to the surrounding stroma within immature proximal villi, or mature terminal villi or as part of a nodular vasoformative lesion.
column47: A nodular benign vasoformative lesion arising in a major stem villus and composed of proliferating capillaries with surrounding pericytes and intervening fibrous stroma.  A variant, localized chorangiomatosis (“wandering chorangioma”) may be spread out amongst several contiguous stem villi.  A presumed genetic condition, recurrent multiple chorangioma syndrome, is characterized by hundreds-thousands of small chorangiomas and is associated with recurrent stillbirth.
column48: More than 10 capillary cross sectional profiles per villus in 10 or more distal villi in several regions of the placenta plus occasional villi with 15-20 capillary cross sectional profiles.
column49: Multiple regions showing excessive capillary growth that forms a network of small anastomosing vessels at the margins of stem and/or immature intermediate villi.  The combination of endothelial cells, pericytes, and adjacent stromal cells resemble chorangioma, but multifocal chorangiomatosis is poorly circumscribed and distributed throughout the placenta.
column50: Focal or diffuse alterations in villous composition and architecture similar to those seen in some early pregnancy specimens with known genetic/chromosomal abnormalities
column51: Irregular villous contour refers to scalloping and fjord-like invaginations affecting the distal villous tree, often accompanied by trophoblast inclusions within the villous stroma.
column52: large edematous proximal villi with truncated distal villi showing accelerated villous maturation and normal proximal villi with uniform undergrowth of distal villi showing either appropriate or delayed maturation for gestational age.
column53: Focal areas with one of more of the following within distal villi: maze-like capillary network, dilated venous sinusoids, or anomalous large muscularized vessels.  May merge or be combined with more common villous capillary lesions, especially in Beckwith Wiedemann-Syndrome.
column54: Patchy to diffuse involvement of distal villi in term or late preterm placentas by some or all of the following characteristics: increased villous diameter, increased stromal cellularity, non-peripheral capillaries, a thickened hypercellular villous trophoblast, persistent cytotrophoblast, decreased vasculosyncytial membranes, placentomegaly, and decreased fetoplacental weight ratio
column55: Restricted fetal blood flow to villous structures due to fetal cardiac insufficiency, obstructed umbilical blood flow, or fetoplacental thrombi.  Placentas (global or segmental pattern) with > 45 affected villi in 3 disc sections (15 avascular villi/section) are considered high grade (sometimes termed fetal thrombotic vasculopathy).
column56: Diffuse reduction in fetal perfusion of placental villi usually due to obstructed umbilical venous blood flow.
column57: Scattered clusters of avascular villi (3 or more foci with 2-4 avascular villi/focus) with stromal fibrosis usually located at the tips of villous trees near the basal plate
column58: Scattered clusters of villi (3 or more foci with 2-4 avascular villi/focus) at the tips of villous trees with cellular necrosis and nuclear karyorrhexis of stromal fibroblasts, endothelial cells, and circulating fetal cells.  Villi also show stromal hypercellularity, mineralization, and entrapped RBC and RBC fragments.
column59: Homogeneous, often laminated, aggregates of fibrin or fibrinoid matrix covered by endothelium located within the intima and/or muscular layer of large fetal veins in the chorionic plate or stem villi.  Remote lesions may show mineralization
column60: Chorionic or major stem villus vessels (presumed veins) with lumen at least four times the diameter of a neighboring vessel (presumed arteries).  Venous origin is confirmed when the dilated vessel is directly below a nondilated vessel within the chorionic plate where arteries always pass over veins.  Umbilical veins may also be dilated.
column61: Pathologic features overlapping with delayed villous maturation-diabetic type (decreased fetoplacental weight ratio, increased villous diameter and stromal cellularity, paucity of vasculosyncytial membranes).  Distinguishing characteristics may include presence of patchy villous stromal edema, an obstructive umbilical cord lesion (e.g. hypercoiling), absence of a thickened, hypercellular villous trophoblast layer, and normal placental weight.
column62: Large (greater than 10 villi) or intermediate (5-10 villi) clusters of completely avascular villi with stromal fibrosis, often in proximity to large fetal vessel thrombi.  Cases with > 45 avascular villi in 3 disc sections (15 avascular villi/section), two or more thrombi (one occlusive), or three or more non-occlusive thrombi are considered high grade.
column63: Large (greater than 10) and/or intermediate (5-10) clusters of completely avascular villi with stromal fibrosis often in proximity to an old or recent large fetal vessel thrombus.
column64: Large (greater than 10) and/or intermediate (5-10) clusters of villi with cellular necrosis (nuclear karyorrhexis/apoptosis) affecting villous stromal fibroblasts, capillary endothelium and/or circulating nucleated fetal cells.  Villi are often hypovascular with stromal hypercellularity, mineralization, and entrapped RBC and RBC fragments are often seen.  Often in proximity to a recent large fetal vessel thrombus.
column65: Organized thrombus within large to intermediate fetal vessel, occlusive or nonocclusive, with 2 or more of the following characteristics: fibrin strands, glassy texture with slight hematoxylin blush, adherence to fetal endothelium.  Two or more thrombi (one occlusive), or three or more non-occlusive thrombi are considered high grade disease.
column66: Concentric narrowing or luminal obliteration of intermediate-large sized fetal vessels by proliferating subintimal fibroblasts.  Sometimes shows bridging luminal septa or multiple small vascular channels and is often associated with entrapped RBC and RBC fragments.
column67: Loss of fetal circulatory integrity due to tissue disruption, vessel wall injury, endothelial permeability, increased hydrostatic pressure, or decreased oncotic pressure.
column68: Organized collection of clotted blood, often angulated and laminated, that are completely surrounded by villi without surrounding infarction.
column69: Increased extracellular fluid within the placental villous tree.  Villous hydrops is defined by edema affecting both proximal and distal villi, often with a surrounding, sometimes discohesive, layer of thickened hypercellular villous trophoblast.  Diffuse villous edema is usually limited to extreme prematurity and is characterized by large lacunar spaces within immature intermediate stem villi.  Focal terminal villous edema is usually limited to term or near term placentas and is defined by small groups of terminal villi with stromal expansion due to excessive extracellular fluid (overlaps with delayed villous maturation- umbilical cord obstructive type).
column70: Disruption of capillary endothelium with hemorrhage into villous stroma.  May form hemosiderin if present for more than 72 hours.
column71: Infiltration of placental tissues by maternal and/or fetal leukocytes secondary to an adaptive and/or innate immune response to allo-, auto-, tissue specific-, or infectious antigen
column72: Maternal and/or fetal leukocytic infiltration of placental tissues secondary to an adaptive and/or innate immune response to infectious antigen
column73: Maternally-derived neutrophilic within the chorion laevae, chorionic plate, with or without involvement of amnionic connective tissue, responding to bacteria or fungi on the amnionic/ umbilical surface epithelium or within the amniotic fluid.  Stage 1 = neutrophils in chorion only, stage 2= amnion plus chorion, stage 3= amnionic epithelial necrosis (stage 0=neutrophils in subchorionic fibrin only).
column74: Fetally-derived neutrophilic within the walls of chorionic vessels, umbilical vein, umblical arteries, and/or chorionic plate stroma and Wharton’s jelly, responding to bacteria or fungi on the amnionic/umbilical surface epithelium or within the amniotic fluid.  Stage 1 = neutrophils in umbilical vein and/or chorionic vessels only, stage 2= neutrophils in the wall of one or both umbilical arteries, stage 3= neutrophils aggregating in an arc-like fashion around umbilical vessels (stage 0=neutrophils marginating on fetal endothelium only).
column75: Neutrophils enter the villous stroma and/or intervillous space in response to bacterial sepsis.  Intervillositis with or without intervillous abscess formation is seen with maternal sepsis, especially that caused by listeria, but also streptococci or enteric bacilli.  Acute villitis combined with intravascular and/or subtrophoblastic bacterial colonies and neutrophils is seen with fetal sepsis, usually caused by enteric bacilli or streptococci.
column76: Focal-patchy mixed lymphohistiocytic infiltrate in chorionic villous stroma often accompanied by edema, fibrosis, calcification, or old villous hemorrhage.  Specific infections have distinct but overlapping features.
column77: Maternal chronic inflammatory infiltrate with admixed neutrophils and fibrin developing within the intervillous space in response to organisms that are not generally capable of crossing the villous trophoblast (e.g. P. falciparum malaria, rickettsia, Chlamydia psittici, Coxsackie A virus, coccidiomycosis)
column78: Chronic inflammation and necrosis, occasionally active (with neutrophils), chronic (with plasma cells), or granulomatous, that is limited to the maternal endometrium (decidua) surrounding the placenta (e.g. mycobacterium tuberculosis, some bacteria).
column79: Maternal and/or fetal leukocytic infiltration of placental tissues secondary to an adaptive and/or innate immune response to noninfectious allo-, auto-, or tissue specific antigen.
column80: Small foci (<10) of distal villi with a lymphocyte-predominant chronic stromal inflammatory infiltrate surrounded by unaffected villi.
column81: Large foci (>10) distal villi with a lymphocyte-predominant chronic stromal inflammatory infiltrate surrounded by unaffected villi.  Often accompanied by proximal villous fetal vascular obliteration, extensive avascular distal villi, and/or diffuse perivillous fibrin deposition
column82: Lymphohistiocytic inflammation of anchoring villi usually associated with lymphoplasmacytic deciduitis in the adjacent decidua basalis (basal plate).
column83: Patchy to diffuse infiltration of the intervillous space by a monomorphic population of monocyte-macrophages without a significant component of chronic villitis.
column84: T Lymphocytic infiltrate within chorionic trophoblast and/or chorioamnionic connective tissue.
column85: An infiltrate of mononuclear cells including plasma cells within the decidua basalis and/or decidua capsularis, usually patchy-diffuse but may be focal
column86: A more or less continuous infiltrate of mononuclear cells lacking plasma cells within the decidua basalis and/or decidua capsularis
column87: Mural inflammation, predominantly fetally-derived eosinophils and T lymphocytes, within the media of large fetal blood vessels in the chorionic plate or stem villi; often involves only one vessel with predominant involvement of the side facing the intervillous space.
column88: Cellular infiltrate of spindled-epithelioid CD68 positive fetal macrophages arranged in a band-like or “lichenoid“ pattern at the base of the of the chorionic plate just above the subchorionic fibrin or occasionally in chorionic connective tissue of the free membranes.
column89: Dysmorphogenesis of placental parenchyma, membranes, and or umbilical cord due to primary developmental abnormalities or secondary physical forces that alter preexisting structure.
column90: Dysmorphogenesis of placental parenchyma, membranes, and or umbilical cord due to early developmental abnormalities
column91: Two distinct fetuses derived from a single zygote with a shared chorionic sac (placenta).  Variants include attachments between fetuses (conjoined twins), a single amniotic cavity (monoamnionic twins), and dizygotic monochorionic twins derived from secondary chorionic fusion of two genetically distinct zygotes after in vitro fertilization/ blastocyst transfer.  Associated syndromes include twin transfusion syndrome (TTS), twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP, acardiac twin), twin anemia polycythemia sequence (TAPS), and stillbirth with CNS damage in co-twin, all developing due to elements of a shared fetal vasculature in the common placenta.
column92: Placenta and fetus are deformed by extensive adhesions between amnion and fetal structures and a short or absent umbilical cord.  Often associated with complete failure of anterior wall closure, lordotic flexure of the spinal column, and lateral continuity between fetal skin and amnion.
column93: Deficient branching and/or extension of chorionic plate vessels ranging from alternative nondichotomous (magistral) branching in “battledore placenta” to localized or global deficiencies of branching resulting in placental shape and umbilical cord insertion site abnormalities.
column94: A trimmed placental weight (after removal of membranes and umbilical cord) falling outside of the 10th to 90th percentile range for gestational age (GA) using the best available population specific standards.
column95: A trimmed placental weight (after removal of membranes and umbilical cord) greater than the 90th percentile for gestational age (GA) using the best available population specific standards.
column96: A trimmed placental weight (after removal of membranes and umbilical cord) less than the 10th percentile for gestational age (GA) using the best available population specific standards.
column97: An elevated ratio of fetal weight/ placental weight (after removal of membranes), greater than the 90th percentile for gestational age (GA) using the best available population specific standards.
column98: A reduced ratio of fetal weight/ placental weight (after removal of membranes), less than the 10th percentile for gestational age (GA) using the best available population specific standards.
column99: Significant variations from a single normally sized round-ovoid placental disc with a smooth peripheral contour
column100: Variations from normal smooth peripheral contour of the placental disc in decreasing order of magnitude: accessory lobe (distinct island of parenchyma separated from the disk by 2 cm or more); bilobed or multilobed placenta (parenchymal indentation(s) of 50% or more), and irregular placental contour (lesser indentations as determined qualitatively by gross inspection).
column101: Rare developmental abnormality characterized by two more or less equal-sized placental lobes separated by membranes that usually contain the umbilical cord insertion site.
column102: Significant variation from the expected value for GA of placenta length (decreased maximum diameter), breadth (decreased minimum diameter), or the difference between length and breadth (increased maximum minus orthogonal minimum diameter).
column103: Very rare condition in which the mature chorionic sac (placenta) is completely or near-completely surrounded by a thin layer of villous parenchyma without a significant component of placental membranes.
column104: Variations from an intact normally coiled, 30-70cm umbilical cord of uniform caliber (1-2cm) containing paired umbilical arteries and a single umbilical vein that inserts paracentrally directly into the placental disc without a restricting fold of amnion and without any associated entanglements, strictures, or true overhand knots
column105: Total length of the umbilical cord falling outside of the 10th to 90th percentile range for gestational age (GA) using standardized tables, usually outside of the 30-70 cm range at term.
column106: Excessively long umbilical cord is commonly defined as greater than 70 cm with greater than 95cm considered extremely long.  These definitions apply to term placentas and standardized tables should be consulted at other gestational ages.
column107: An abnormally short umbilical cord, less than the 10th percentile for gestational age (GA), commonly less than 30 cm at term.  Short umbilical cord can only be diagnosed if submission of the entire umbilical cord can be confirmed, something rarely known with certainty.
column108: Diffuse or localized abnormalities in umbilical cord caliber or coiling.
column109: A thin UC (diffusely decreased Wharton’s jelly) has been defined as less than 0.8 cm in maximum thickness as measured on a slide containing two or more representative sections.
column110: A hypercoiled umbilical cord has more than 3 diagonal grooves in a 10 cm segment (>0.3/cm).  Separated into four groups based on the degree of indentation between coils: undulating, rope-like (both non-indented), segmented (less than 50% indentation), and linked (greater than 50% indentation).
column111: Umbilical cord strictures are regions of narrowing (less than 1.3 mm diameter), occasionally multiple, most frequently seen near the fetal umbilicus.
column112: Variation from the normal state of a freely movable, paracentrally inserted umbilical cord completely surrounded by Wharton’s jelly
column113: Umbilical cord is inserted in the placental membranes, lateral to the placenta (= type 1 vasa previa, if bridging vessels cross the cervical os).  Occasionally, the cord inserts in the placenta, but an aberrant “wandering” chorionic vessel partially traverses the membranes (=type 3 vasa previa, if vessel crosses the cervical os).
column114: Umbilical cord is inserted in the placental disc, 0.5 cm or less from the nearest margin.
column115: Umbilical cord is inserted in the placental disc less than 3 cm from the margin.
column116: Umbilical cord is inserted into the placental disc, but there is premature termination of Wharton’s jelly leaving splayed (“fork-like”) distal vessels travelling unprotected within a “veil” of surrounding amnion.  An exaggeration of this “amnionic veil”, a fold of amnion containing the umbilical vessels tethered to the surface of the chorionic plate is termed “furcate insertion with interposition”.
column117: Insertion of a normal umbilical cord into the placental disc, but with lateral mobility restricted by a “tethering” fold of amnion.
column118: Variations in the number, identity, and morphology of the major umbilical vessels plus vascular proliferations, malformations, or tumors arising from them.
column119: One or more umbilical cord sections contain a single artery, normally arising from either the right or left fetal internal iliac artery (Type1), but rarely arising from the vitelline circulation (type 2) at or below the superior mesenteric artery.  A related abnormality is single umbilical artery with a second hypoplastic or atretic umbilical artery.
column120: One or more umbilical cord sections contains two paired arteries plus two additional large vessels with venous morphology.  The extra vein represents persistence and abnormal umbilical extension of the right umbilical vein.
column121: Aneurysmal dilatation of a major umbilical vessel due to attenuation of and/or damage to the vessel wall; usually associated with intrafunicular hemorrhage and/or longitudinal dissection along the vessel wall.
column122: Large intrafuncicular pseudocyst within Wharton’s jelly adjacent to a nodular vascular proliferative lesion arising from a major umbilical vessel.
column123: Large vascular lesion, often located near the placental insertion site, composed of thin-walled dilated venous spaces lined by an attenuated layer of inactive endothelium with or without adjacent arterial vessels.  Organizing luminal thrombi are common.
column124: Incidental microscopic finding consisting of branching small vessels within Wharton’s jelly arising from a persistent vitelline vessel.
column125: True cysts of the umbilical cord can arise from the remnants of early embryonic ducts that travel in the umbilical cord - (1) omphalomesenteric (vitelline) duct: intestinal-type epithelium  or (2) allantoic duct:  transitional + squamous/glandular - or from umbilical surface epithelial invaginations (inclusion cysts: simple squamous epithelium).  Pseudocysts are mucoid-serous fluid filled cavities that lack an epithelial lining.  These may occasionally be associated with an adjacent vascular lesion (angiomyxoma).
column126: Microscopic persistence of the allantoic duct is observed in up to 14.5% of term placentas and is generally located between the umbilical arteries.  Cyst formation is uncommon and remnants lack smooth muscle, a feature useful in differentiating them from omphalomesenteric duct remnants.  Allantoic remnants communicating with the urachus may form large urine-filled cysts near the umbilicus.
column127: Microscopic persistence of the omphalomesenteric duct is observed in up to 1.4% of term placentas and has no consistent location within the umbilical cord.  It is lined by intestinal type-mucinous epithelium and more commonly gives rise to recognizable cysts than allantoic duct remnants.  Remnants communicating with the fetal intestine at the umbilicus may be associated with Meckel’s diverticulum or fetal omphalocele.
column128: Small simple squamous epithelial-lined inclusions located just below the surface epithelium of the umbilical cord.
column129: Pseudocysts are mucoid-serous fluid filled cavities that lack an epithelial lining.  They may occasionally be associated with an adjacent vascular lesion (angiomyxoma).
column130: Foci of fetal tissue located within, but not native to, the placenta
column131: Microscopic nodules of adrenocortical tissue identified within placental tissue, usually within large stem villi or under the chorionic plate.
column132: Well-circumscribed nodules of benign fetal-type liver tissue portal vascular and biliary structures found in placental tissue, usually at the periphery of large stem villi or under the chorionic plate.
column133: Primary tumors arising within the placenta.  (For extravillous trophoblastic tumors invading the uterus after delivery and tumors metastatic to placenta see cited references).
column134: Nodular mass consisting of disorganized mature ectodermal, mesodermal, and endodermal tissues generally located between amnion and chorion on the chorionic plate or attached to the base of the umbilical cord.  Presence of an umbilical cord or axially oriented skeletal structures excludes teratoma and suggests an acardiac twin.
column135: Malignant neoplasm of primitive endodermal differentiation that can include yolk sac epithelium, primitive mesenchyme, enteric glands, and/or hepatic tissue.
column136: Highly malignant neoplasm of villous trophoblastic origin arising within the placenta.  Nodular tumors show a biphasic pattern with groups of 10–50 mononuclear cytotrophoblast surrounded by multinucleate syncytiotrophoblast, often with central necrosis.
column137: Perturbations of otherwise normal placental structures owing to external forces or noxious agents.
column138: placental findings associated with early or late rupture of the membranous amnion, chorion, or both
column139: Numerous small white nodules composed of degenerating superficial squamous cell from the fetal skin adherent to the amnion covering the chorionic disc and extraplacental membranes (usually indicates lethal pulmonary hypoplasia in the accompanying fetus).
column140: Bands of amnion-derived connective tissue extending from the fetal surface of the placenta to encircle and/or amputate fetal structures.  Also may encircle the umbilical cord restricting fetoplacental blood flow.
column141: Dissection and organization of amniotic fluid debris (vernix, superficial squamous cells, and/or lanugo hair) between the amnion and chorion at delivery.
column142: Traumatic laceration or avulsion of a large muscularized fetal vessel in the umbilical cord, chorionic plate, or fetal membranes.  Ruptured vasa previa occurs when the lacerated vessel overlies the cervical os.  Three subtypes of vasa previa have been identified based on the underlying placental anomaly: type 1 – associated with membranous UC insertion, type 2 – associated with abnormal placental shape, and type 3 – associated with an aberrant membranous vessel extending from the chorionic plate.
column143: Exposure of amnion, umbilical cord surface epithelium, and underlying fibrovascular tissues to the caustic effects of meconium, fetal gastric acid, or other corrosive substances.
column144: Placental changes attributable to meconium exposure of less than one day’s duration including green staining, membrane edema, amnion necrosis and “epithelial (pseudo)hyperplasia”, and vacuolated macrophages with fine red-brown pigment in the amnion or superficial chorion
column145: Placental changes attributable to meconium exposure of more than one day: (1) early- abundant pigment laden macrophages in chorionic plate or umbilical stroma; (2) late- pigment laden macrophages in large fetal vessel wall, meconium associated vascular (myo) necrosis
column146: Surface ulceration of the umbilical cord in a spiral pattern following the course of the umbilical vessels.  Range of findings: loss of Wharton’s jelly, exteriorization of umbilical cord vessels, segmental loss of large fetal vessel muscular wall, large fetal vessel rupture.
column147: Any placental finding attributable to variations from the normal state of a biparental euploid genome without significant sequence abnormalities
column148: Placental findings that are attributable to variations from the normal state of a euploid genome without significant sequence abnormalities
column149: Placental findings attributable to global (both fetus and placenta affected) variation from the normal state of a euploid genome without significant sequence abnormalities.  In addition to nonviable states such as anembryonic pregnancy and hydropic abortion, aneuploidy or polyploidy are associated with abnormal villus morphology/ dysmorphic villi (irregular villous contour, trophoblast inclusions, nonspecific trophoblast hyperplasia, stromal nuclear karyomegaly, abnormal vascular patterning, and/or villous cisterns) in some cases.
column150: Findings that are attributable to chromosomal variations, usually postmeiotic aneuploidy or polyploidy, confined to the placenta (i.e. fetus not affected).  Fragmentary evidence suggests these may include decreased placental size and weight, maternal vascular malperfusion, and focally hydropic villi.  Whether other dysmorphic features (atypical villus histology) can be seen has not been established.
column151: Placental findings attributable to specific genetic mutations that cause histologic (or ultrastructural) changes such as vacuolated trophoblast in lysosomal storage disease, trophoblast basement membrane calcification in Bartter syndrome, and, possibly, massive perivillous fibrin deposition in LCHAD deficiency.
column152: Placental findings in euploid gestations without significant sequence abnormalities that are attributable to an unbalanced contribution of maternally and paternally derived DNA (can include noncoding DNA, genes, chromosomes, or entire haploid sets of chromosomes).  Includes trophoblast hyperplasia or neoplasia (complete hydatidiform mole), mesenchymal dysplasia (androgenetic biparental mosaicism chimerism and some cases of Beckwith Wiedemann syndrome), placentomegaly, villous capillary lesions, and increased perivillous fibrin (Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, and small placentas (Russell-Silver syndrome).
column153: Early placenta with marked villous trophoblast hyperplasia and villous cavitation (failure of fetal stromal-vascular development) due to the overexpression of critical paternally-derived genes.  At risk for trophoblast neoplasia (persistent gestational trophoblastic disease) and malignancy (choriocarcinoma or, less commonly, other trophoblastic tumors).
column154: Abnormal placenta, often enlarged, with segmental areas showing dilated tortuous chorionic plate vessels and enlarged abnormal proximal villi with cysts, fibroblastic stromal overgrowth, and vascular abnormalities affecting vessels of all caliber (mesenchymal dysplasia).  Occasional cases can contain focal areas of complete hydatidiform mole in the placenta and/or androgenetic tumors in the fetus (hepatic mesenchymal hamartomas, vascular malformations)
column155: Placentas can show a wide range of phenotypes varying from mild (placentomegaly and villous capillary lesions) to intermediate (increased perivillous fibrin with extravillous trophoblast atypia), culminating in mesenchymal dysplasia (dilated tortuous chorionic plate vessels and enlarged proximal villi with cysts, stromal overgrowth, and more severe villous vascular abnormalities).
column156: Specific placental lesions associated with uniparental disomy have not yet been described.

column2: Intrinsic or extrinsic abnormalities affecting the normal differentiation of extravillous trophoblast, the maternal uterus and its vasculature, and their interactions during placentation and early development.
column3: Early hypoxia, underlying maternal vascular disease, and trophoblast release of antiangiogenic factors impair trophoblast differentiation, invasion, and remodeling of uterine spiral arteries
column4: Intrinsic or extrinsic abnormalities leading to deficient invasion by extravillous trophoblast.  Defects are associated with dysregulation of integrin expression in the distal cytotrophoblast columns.
column5: Failure of endovascular extravillous trophoblast to appropriately invade and remodel spiral arteries distal to the inner third of the myometrium (specifically within basal plate/ decidua basalis)
column6: Invasive extravillous trophoblast coalesce to form placental site giant cells when they reach their maximum trajectory of implantation.  This should normally occur deep within the myometrium.
column7: Uterine spiral arterioles in patients with underlying maternal vascular disease may show mural hypertrophy mimicking arteriolosclerosis.  Ischemic and/or developmentally abnormal impaired trophoblast can release antiangiogenic molecules including s-flt-1 and sEng that can cause endothelial injury, medial necrosis, and adventitial chronic inflammation.
column8: Microvascular disease with pathogenesis similar to that seen with diabetes and/or essential hypertension.  Changes may also relate to abnormal trophoblast-independent uterine arterial remodeling.
column9: Abnormal pregnancy-related remodeling of spiral arteries combined with early degenerative changes in the vessel wall secondary to circulating antioangiogenic molecules in the maternal blood.
column10: Endothelial damage, insudation of plasma, and myointimal proliferation and lipid accumulation followed by ingress of macrophages that phagocytose extracellular lipid.
column11: Absent or defective decidualization of endometrium separating the anchoring villi from myometrium.  Proposed roles for abnormal local immune response, abnormal myometrial architecture, and increased invasiveness of extravillous trophoblast are unproven.
column12: The normal plane of separation between placenta and uterus at delivery is within the gestational endometrium (intradecidual).  Artificial separation of the placenta by blunt dissection at C-section or abnormal endometrial anatomy can lead to smooth muscle cells being delivered with the placenta.
column13: Absence or defective decidualization of endometrium separating the anchoring villi from myometrium.  Proposed roles for abnormal local immunity, abnormal myometrial architecture, and increased invasiveness affecting extravillous trophoblast in the proximal cytotrophoblast columns are unproven.
column14: Uterine invasion may be due to defective endometrium, adenomyosis, abnormal inner myometrial anatomy, impaired uterine killer cell function, or abnormal extravillous trophoblast differentiation (none proven).
column15: Uterine invasion could be due to defective endometrium, adenomyosis, abnormal inner myometrial anatomy, impaired uterine killer cell function, or abnormal extravillous trophoblast differentiation (none proven).
column16: Primary or secondary failure of integrity of scar tissue at a previous hysterotomy site, most commonly follows a transverse lower uterine segment type C-section
column17: Primary or acquired defects in trophoblast differentiation lead to the accumulation of excessive immature (transitional) extravillous trophoblast.  This is best characterized in the basal plate where extravillous trophoblast fail to express the alpha 1 integrin cell surface proteins required for optimal tissue invasion.
column18: Primary or acquired defects in trophoblast differentiation lead to the accumulation of excessive immature (transitional) extravillous trophoblast.
column19: Primary or acquired defects in trophoblast differentiation lead to the accumulation of excessive immature (transitional) extravillous trophoblast.
column20: Primary or acquired defects in trophoblast differentiation lead to the accumulation of excessive immature (transitional) extravillous trophoblast which undergoes central cystification.
column21: Defective spiral artery remodeling and arteriopathy results in a reduced volume of maternal blood entering the placental cotyledons at increased velocity leading to global stasis, ischemia, sheer stress, apoptosis, and focal tissue necrosis and/or segmental occlusion of one or more spiral arteries causing ischemic necrosis of the overlying villous parenchyma.
column22: Defective spiral artery remodeling and arteriopathy lead to a reduced volume of maternal blood entering the placental cotyledons at increased velocity.
column23: Defective spiral artery remodeling and arteriopathy lead to a reduced volume of maternal blood entering the placental cotyledons at increased velocity.  Preferential blood flow to non-gas exchanging villi in the upper 1/3 of the placenta plus rapid egress due to developing abnormal cotyledonary architecture leads to stasis, ischemia, sheer stress, apoptosis, and focal tissue necrosis causing excessive syncytial knots, villous agglutination and fibrin deposition, and reduced villous growth.
column24: Distal villous hypoplasia is most likely a severe early onset form of maternal vascular malperfusion occurring at a time period preceding normal villous branching and terminal villogenesis.  Abnormalities in villous trophoblast differentiation and development are suggested by abnormal values in maternal serum screening for fetal aneuploidy.
column25: Distal villous hypoplasia is most likely a severe early onset form of maternal vascular malperfusion occurring at a time period preceding normal villous branching and terminal villogenesis.  Abnormalities in villous trophoblast differentiation and development are suggested by abnormal values in maternal serum screening for fetal aneuploidy.
column26: Segmental complete loss of maternal perfusion in the territory of one or more spiral arteries due to either thrombosis or premature separation of the placenta causes ischemic necrosis of villous parenchyma.  Inherited or acquired thrombophilic states may increase risk of segmental maternal malperfusion (infarcts) as opposed to global maternal malperfusion alone.
column27: Complete loss of maternal perfusion in the territory of one or more spiral arteries due to either thrombosis or premature placental separation (abruption) leads to ischemic necrosis of villous parenchyma.  Inherited or acquired thrombophilic states increase the risk of segmental maternal malperfusion (infarcts), as opposed to global maternal malperfusion alone.
column28: Complete loss of maternal perfusion in the territory of one or more spiral arteries due to either thrombosis or premature placental separation l(abruption) eads to schemic necrosis of villous parenchyma.  Inherited or acquired thrombophilic states increase the risk of segmental maternal malperfusion (infarcts) as opposed to global maternal malperfusion alone.
column29: Spiral arteries may rupture prematurely due to intrinsic defects in the vessel wall due to decidual arteriopathy, ischemia reperfusion, or trauma.  Decidual veins, particularly at the placental margins may rupture prematurely due to surrounding inflammation, intrinsically poor structural support, or changes in uterine geometry secondary to ruptures membranes or other cause of oligohydramnios.
column30: Spiral arteries can rupture prematurely due to intrinsic defects in the vessel wall due to decidual arteriopathy (preeclampsia), ischemia reperfusion (thrombosis, cocaine, smoking), or sheer stress (trauma, hard physical labor, uterine rupture).
column31: Spiral arteries can rupture prematurely due to intrinsic defects in the vessel wall due to decidual arteriopathy (preeclampsia), ischemia reperfusion (thrombosis, cocaine, smoking), or sheer stress (trauma, hard physical labor, uterine rupture).
column32: Decidual veins at the placental margins prematurely rupture due to surrounding acute inflammation, intrinsically poor structural support, or changes in uterine geometry following rupture of membranes or other cause of oligohydramnios.  Acute separation is usually followed by rapid delivery.  Manifest histologically by marginal retroplacental and retromembranous hemorrhage with intradecidual spread and, often, elevation of the overlying placental parenchyma.
column33: Decidual veins, particularly at the placental margins rupture due to poor structural support or changes in uterine geometry following rupture of membranes or other cause of oligohydramnios.  Chronic separation usually leads to organizing marginal or subchorionic hematomas and/or circumvallate membrane insertion.
column35: Hypotheses: (1) stasis, villous trophoblast surface damage, and/or hypercoagulability leads to fibrin-type fibrinoid deposition; (2) villous trophoblast injury triggers extravillous-type trophoblast metaplasia with secretion of matrix-type fibrinoid.
column36: Benign sequestration of distal villi by surrounding fibrin or fibrinoid due to irregular local flow and/or villous surface damage.
column37: Hypotheses: (1) stasis, villous trophoblast surface damage, and/or hypercoagulability leads to fibrin-type fibrinoid deposition; (2) villous trophoblast injury triggers extravillous-type trophoblast metaplasia with secretion of matrix-type fibrinoid.  Often recurs in subsequent pregnancies.
column38: Lesions in this category may represent local imbalances in intervillous blood flow, retroplacental hemorrhages that have dissected through the basal plate to enter the intervillous space, fetal hemorrhage from disrupted intraplacental fetal vessels, or combinations thereof.
column39: Two competing theories: (1) rupture of decidual artery through the basal plate into the intervillous space with subsequent compression or infarction of adjacent villi and (2) ischemic villous infarction followed by reperfusion causing central hemorrhage.
column40: Hypotheses include local abnormalities in intervillous blood flow, poorly developed villous trees, hypercoagulability, and even rupture of stem villi with subsequent maternal blood clot.
column41: Stasis or turbulence of blood flow in the maternal circulation at the roof of the intervillous space. Irregularities on the maternal side of the chorionic plate may lead to stasis or tissue injury and thrombus formation.
column42: Hypotheses include thrombosis and rupture of a maternal decidual vein, abruptio placentae with oblique intraplacental extension, or benign local circulatory stasis.
column43: Suprabasal blood and fibrin with organization via ingrowth of myofibroblasts from maternal tissues in the basal plate.  Larger lesions bridging multiple anchoring villi may be markers of more global placental pathology.
column44: inherited or acquired variations in the normal architecture and function of the fetal vascular supply of the placenta and its supporting architecture
column45: Intrinsic or acquired modulation of lineage-specific gene expression in the fetal stromal-vascular compartment lead to developmental alterations
column46: Hypoxemia, angiogenic growth factors, and their regulators lead to capillary proliferation via activation of mesenchymal stem cells, vascular progenitor cells, endothelial cells, and/or pericytes.
column47: Possibly triggered by reduced oxygen tension in areas rich in mesenchymal stem cells and endothelial progenitor cells (margins of chorionic plate and major stem villi)[.  Whether they are clonal lesions has not been established.  Histologically they resemble infantile hemangiomas.  Both express Glut-1 by immunohistochemistry and are thought to derive from placental mesenchymal stem cells/ endothelial progenitor cells that either proliferate locally or enter the fetal circulation during late gestation or parturition.
column48: Excessive elongation and branching of villous capillaries leading to appearance of increased cross sections on two dimensional placental sections.  Some evidence suggests origin early in the first trimester. Increased capillarization due to hypoxemia is associated with increased glutathione, but not elevation in markers of hypoxic stress such as HIF-1 alpha.   Increased capillarization associated with diabetes is believed to develop via fetal hyperglycemia, increased fetal insulin, and insulin/ IGF-1 receptor mediated angiogenesis.
column49: Reactive proliferative process involving the paravascular capillary network that surrounds immature intermediate and stem villi.  Pathogenesis may involve delayed maturation of immature intermediate villi combined with obstructed fetal blood flow.
column50: Potential pathogenetic mechanisms in placentas with an apparently normal fetal karyotype include confined placental mosaicism, placental chimerism, placenta-specific mutations that are silent in the fetus, or epigenetic modifications affecting placental gene expression. These processes might act at a cellular level to alter the balance between tissue morphogens, relative proliferative rates, and cellular differentiation.
column51: Inclusions may, in some cases, represent oblique sections of villi with irregular contour.  Alternatively, it has been suggested that they develop by internalization of villous trophoblast vesicles due to increased proliferation of cytotrophoblast relative to syncytiotrophoblast.
column52: Potential pathogenetic mechanisms in placentas with an apparently normal fetal karyotype include confined placental mosaicism, placental chimerism, placenta-specific mutations that are silent in the fetus, or epigenetic modifications affecting placental gene expression. These processes might act at a cellular level to alter the balance between tissue morphogens, relative proliferative rates, and cellular differentiation.
column53: Potential pathogenetic mechanisms in placentas with an apparently normal fetal karyotype include confined placental mosaicism, placental chimerism, placenta-specific mutations that are silent in the fetus, or epigenetic modifications affecting placental gene expression. These processes might act at a cellular level to alter the balance between tissue morphogens, relative proliferative rates, and cellular differentiation.
column54: Inappropriate lack of terminal villous differentiation, possibly related to continuing new villous growth or a block in the capacity to convert immature intermediate villi to mature intermediate and terminal villi.  Increased levels of villous growth factors such as fetal insulin in diabetes may be involved.
column55: Pathogenic processes, most frequently related to umbilical cord obstruction, lead to either chronic partial reduction in fetal blood flow to the entire placenta or segmental complete absence of flow in chorionic or stem villous vessels due to the formation of thrombi.  Vascular stasis, maternal or fetal thrombophilia, hyperviscosity, fetal cardiac insufficiency, or an elongated pathway (long umbilical cord) all increase the risk of thrombosis.
column56: Various conditions, most frequently umbilical cord entanglements or other obstructive lesions, cause a chronic/ partial intermittent obstruction of flow that affects the entire villous tree (global/ partial) leading to reduced perfusion and degenerative changes in the most distal portions of the villous tree.  Hyperviscosity, fetal cardiac insufficiency, or an elongated pathway (long umbilical cord) may act synergistically to reduce flow to a critical level.
column57: Prolonged global reduction in villous blood flow, usually due to umbilical venous obstruction, leads to loss of fetal capillaries in the distal-most regions of villous trees.
column58: Early stage of global reduction in villous blood flow, usually due to umbilical venous obstruction, leading to cellular necrosis in the distal-most regions of villous trees.
column59: Generally attributed to elevated pressure due to umbilical venous obstruction resulting in either insudation of fibrin or deposition of fibrinoid extracellular matrix.  Some cases be caused by reduced endothelial integrity due to vasoactive mediators or remote thrombi that are incorporated into the vessel wall.
column60: Physiologically significant umbilical cord compression causes venous dilatation.  Chronic or partial intermittent obstruction sufficient to cause fixed ectasia of veins is considered clinically significant.
column61: Increased venous pressure due to chronic umbilical cord obstruction causes mild edema that may retard terminal villous development via unknown mechanisms.  Similar findings are seen with treated immune hydrops fetalis.
column62: Various conditions, most frequently umbilical cord obstruction, lead to fetal vascular stasis, occlusive thrombosis of chorionic or stem villous vessels, and subsequent degenerative changes in all downstream villi perfused by the affected vessel.  Maternal or fetal thrombophilia, diabetes, hyperviscosity, fetal cardiac insufficiency, or an elongated pathway (long umbilical cord) may increase risk of thrombosis.
column63: Late stage of villous degeneration secondary to thrombosis of chorionic or stem villous vessels and segmental loss of fetal blood flow to distal portions of the villous tree.
column64: Early stage of villous degeneration secondary to thrombosis of chorionic or stem villous vessels and segmental loss of fetal blood flow to distal portions of the villous tree.
column65: Thrombi form due to vascular stasis, hypercoagulability, and/or endothelial activation/ damage.  Placental inflammatory processes involving large fetal vessels, acute chorioamnionitis or chronic villitis, may play a role in some cases.
column66: Involutional process that gradually obliterates the fetal stem villous vessels lying between an occlusive large fetal vessel thrombus and downstream avascular villi.
column67: Trauma, vasoactive mediators, and pressure gradients interact with placental regions at risk, tissue necrosis, and abnormal tissue architecture to cause hemorrhage or edema.
column68: Maternal blood flow leads to shear stresses that disrupt terminal villi allowing small amounts of fetal blood to enter the intervillous space.  Exposed collagen and/or fetal maternal blood group incompatibility trigger local coagulation forming a protective maternal blood clot that “seals off” the leak.
column69: All forms of edema are related to combinations of increased hydrostatic pressure, decreased oncotic pressure, or increased vascular permeability.  Villous hydrops is most commonly associated with fetal heart failure, diffuse villous edema with developmental immaturity, and focal terminal villous edema with umbilical venous obstruction, but other factors may contribute.
column70: Most commonly seen in preterm placentas with abruption.  Thought to reflect elevated capillary pressure and/or endothelial ischemic necrosis due to sudden hypoxia.  Other possible etiologies include sudden fetal venous outflow obstruction with umbilical cord accidents, traumatic injury due to curettage, or acute endothelial injury due to viral infections.
column71: Organisms enter the uteroplacental environment via the ascending route from vagina, via the hematogenous route through the intervillous space, or by spread from contiguous pelvic organs.  The immune system can also react to noninfectious fetoplacental antigens secondary to immune dysregulation, host versus graft reactivity, or exposure to novel tissue specific (“oncofetal”) antigens.
column72: Organisms enter the uteroplacental environment via the ascending route from vagina, via the hematogenous route through the intervillous space and across villi, or by spread from contiguous pelvic organs.
column73: Microbial pattern-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) activate chemotactic pathways facilitating the emigration of circulating maternal neutrophils from membranous decidual capillaries to the decidual-chorionic interface and beyond and from intervillous blood through subchorionic fibrin to the connective tissues of the chorionic plate plus or minus the overlying amnion.
column74: Microbial pattern-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) activate chemotactic pathways stimulating circulating fetal neutrophils to marginate on, transmigrate through, and enter the connective tissue around fetoplacental veins and arteries in the umbilical cord and/or chorionic plate. Fetal neutrophils in the chorionic plate may also enter the amniotic fluid and be aspirated into the fetal lungs.
column75: Neutrophilic response to microorganisms entering the villous stroma from the maternal or fetal blood streams.
column76: Circulating organisms in maternal blood, most commonly viruses but occasionally spirochetes or protozoans (toxoplasma, trypanosomes), cross from the intervillous space through the villous trophoblast to enter the villous stroma, causing either a primary local infection or spreading back to the placenta villi as a consequence of systemic fetal infection.  The inflammatory response can be maternal and/or fetal in origin.
column77: Viruses, fungi, chlamydia, rickettsia, and some parasites enter the intervillous space and elicit a maternal inflammatory response, especially in previously uninfected mothers.  Specific cellular receptors on trophoblast may facilitate placental sequestration in some cases (e.g. P. falciparum malaria).
column78: Infection of maternal endometrium only without spread into chorionic tissues. Can precede pregnancy, be initiated by hematogenous spread of organisms during pregnancy, or in rare cases spread during gestation from contiguous organs (cervicovaginal tract, fallopian tubes, across myometrium).
column79: The maternal immune system can react to noninfectious fetoplacental antigens in the context of immune dysregulation, host versus graft reactivity, or exposure to novel tissue specific (“oncofetal”) antigens particularly in the presence of inflammatory costimulatory signals.  Non-infection driven fetal immune responses may also occur (e.g. fetal eosinophilic/T cell vasculitis
column80: Maternal T lymphocytes, most frequently of the CD8-positive memory phenotype, enter villi through breaks in the trophoblastic barrier, encounter fetal antigen on fetal macrophages, and in the proper costimulatory environment proliferate and undergo differentiation to an effector phenotype resulting in local stromal chronic inflammation in distal villi.
column81: Maternal T lymphocytes, most frequently of the CD8 positive memory phenotype, enter villi through breaks in the trophoblastic barrier, encounter fetal antigen on fetal macrophages, and in the proper costimulatory environment proliferate and undergo differentiation to an effector phenotype resulting in diffuse chronic inflammation spreading within the villous tree and the release of T cell cytokines and chemokines into the fetal circulation.
column82: Basal villitis may have a similar pathogenesis to chronic villitis, but is more likely to include B lymphocytes and is more frequent with prior genitourinary tract infections, morbidly adherent placentas (accreta), and preeclampsia.  It is also increased in ovum donation pregnancies and neonatal alloimmune thrombocytopenia suggesting an alloimmune component in some cases.
column83: Maternal inflammatory cells (approximately 80% CD68-positive monocyte-macrophages and 20% T lymphocytes with an equal CD4/CD8 ratio) accumulate within the intervillous space, often in contact with the surface of syncytiotrophoblast.  Evidence suggests an adaptive immune response to antigens, possibly paternally encoded, on the trophoblastic surface.  Frequently occurs in women with underlying autoimmune disease.
column84: Like noninfectious chronic villitis (VUE), chronic chorioamnionitis is considered to be a maternal anti-fetal immune response.  Unlike VUE, it is most commonly observed in preterm gestations and the inflammatory infiltrate is limited to the membranes. The membranes constitute another fetomaternal interface where maternal immune cells in the decidua could react to fetal chorionic trophoblast.
column85: Poorly understood, but may represent either an immune-related adaptive immune response to allo-, auto-, tissue specific oncofetal, or microbial antigens.  Often accompanied by coexistant basal villitis.  Increased in cases with history of genitourinary infection, preeclampsia, or ovum donation pregnancy.
column86: Very poorly understood, but could reflect excessive uterine NK cells, immune-related adaptive immune responses to allo- or autoantigens, or the remnants of old endometrial infection.  May overlap with chronic chorioamnionitis and lymphoplasmacytic deciduitis.
column87: Considered a fetal response to vascular injury, but has a strong association with idiopathic chronic villitis (VUE) so maternal alloreactivity could play a role in initiation.  Anecdotally associated with later atopy in affected fetuses.  Occasionally associated with coexisting luminal thrombi.
column88: Fetally derived (as determined by Y chromosome specific FISH in male fetuses) cellular inflammatory response most commonly accompanying other noninfectious chronic inflammatory conditions (villitis, chorioamnionitis, and deciduitis).  Also may be seen with prolonged meconium exposure or longstanding subacute infectious chorioamnionitis.
column89: Abnormal gene expression (caused by teratogens, maternal/ fetal regulators) and/or physical forces (trauma, fetal movement, altered uterine geometry) lead to abnormal size, shape and structure or the presence of cells and tissues not usually found in normal placentas.
column90: Extraplacental factors cause alterations in placentation, ventral embryonic body wall closure, early amniogenesis, or fetal placental vasculogenesis.
column91: Current dogma is that monochorionic placentas develop in identical twins secondary to very late fission of the embryonic disk after the formation of a single placenta.  A contrarian view is that fission always occurs early and that monochorionic twins represent the secondary fusion of separate, but contiguous, early implanting blastocysts.  All monochorionic placentas are believed to have at least some shared fetal circulation: connection of arteries to veins or unequal perfusion pressure can cause intertwin shunting resulting in a spectrum of consequences listed in increasing order of gestational age at onset of development (see definitions): TRAP, TTS, TAPS, and CNS damage following stillbirth of the cotwin.
column92: Pathogenesis is controversial in terms of which occurs first, early rupture of the amnion leading to fetal adhesions or abnormal body wall closure leading to primary failure in amnion development.  In the extreme phenotype, Type 3 UC agenesis -also known as Limb Body Wall Sequence, type 2, body stalk vessels travel outside the UC in a short membranous fold before directly inserting into the placenta.  Fetus typically has eventration of abdominal contents, cloacal abnormalities, and marked deformation of the limbs and spinal column secondary to forced apposition of the conceptus to the placenta and membranes.  The fetus is enclosed in amnion, but the abdominal contents are free in the extraembryonic coelom.
column93: Fetal vasculogenesis in the chorionic plate is incompletely understood.  Developmental dysregulation may lead to nondichotomous (monopodal/magistral/perpendicular branching off a major trunk) branching, which is clinically benign, to incomplete coverage of the chorionic surface leading to parenchymal deficiencies in “watershed” zones between vessels.  These may predispose to growth restriction, preterm delivery, or vasa previa.  Placental shape abnormalities attributable to branching abnormalities can be detected as early as 14 weeks gestation by ultrasound.
column94: Abnormally small placentas may accompany proportionally small fetuses, both of which lack abnormalities (constitutionally small) or may show evidence of pathologic processes associated with reduced placental growth (e.g. maternal or fetal vascular malperfusion, chronic inflammatory disorders, massive perivillous fibrin deposition).  Abnormally large placentas may accompany proportionally large fetuses, both of which lack abnormalities (constitutionally large) or may show evidence of pathologic processes associated with increased placental growth (e.g. diabetes, delayed villous maturation, fetal stromal-vascular overgrowth).
column95: Abnormally large placentas may accompany proportionally large fetuses, both of which lack abnormalities (constitutionally large) or may show evidence of pathologic processes associated with increased placental growth (e.g. diabetes, delayed villous maturation, fetal stromal-vascular overgrowth).  Less common causes include edema (hydrops fetalis) and developmental abnormalities (e.g. Beckwith Wiedmann syndrome).
column96: Abnormally small placentas may accompany proportionally small fetuses, both of which lack abnormalities (constitutionally small) or may show evidence of pathologic processes associated with reduced placental growth (e.g. maternal or fetal vascular malperfusion, chronic inflammatory disorders, massive perivillous fibrin deposition).  Less common causes are disadvantageous implantation site (e.g. underlying leiomyoma, lower uterine segment) and developmental anomalies (e.g. aneuploidy).
column97: In most cases an increased fetoplacental weight ratio (FPR) is believed to reflect reduced placental growth (villous paucity and distal villous hypoplasia) due to the direct effects of maternal vascular malperfusion and the secondary effects of shunting fetal nutrients away from the placenta to other vital fetal organs.  Destruction of placental parenchyma by tissue necrosis may also contribute.
column98: In most cases a decreased fetoplacental weight ratio (FPR) is believed to reflect increased placental growth (fetal stromal-vascular compartment) due to the direct effects of excessive placental growth factors and the secondary effects of fetal hyperinsulinemia related to maternal hyperglycemia.  Expansion of placental parenchyma by edema may also contribute.
column99: Abnormalities in early implantation, fetal chorionic vasculogenesis, and peripheral membrane formation can lead to irregular, multilobed, and abnormally sized placentas that are at risk for intrapartum complications or adverse outcomes.
column100: Two theories have been proposed: (1) trophotropism which suggests that placentas become irregular by preferentially occupying richly vascularized uterine tissue and avoiding less well vascularized areas, such as the lower uterine segment, uterine scars, or leiomyomas.   (2) abnormal placental surface chorionic surface network which suggests that deficient growth and branching of large chorionic plate vessels in the late first trimester creates parenchymal deficiencies in “watershed” zones that cannot be completely “filled in” by later villous development.  The two theories are not mutually exclusive.
column101: Bilobate placentation has been modeled by proposing an elongated axis of fetal chorionic vasculogenesis, stunted along its axis but more active at each end.  An older theory of bilobate placenta is that very early shallow implantation might lead to significant parenchymal development on both sides of the endometrial cavity.  Bilobate placentas are normally found in some lower primates.
column102: Decreased maximum diameter has been related to superficial implantation and a lack of endovascular trophoblast plugs at the lateral edges of the implantation site.  This deficiency increases marginal oxygen tension, stimulates parenchymal to membrane conversion, and reduces the final placental diameter in one or more dimensions.  One theory posits that placental length (rostrocaudal) is genetically determined while breadth (lateral growth) is conditional based on the supply of maternal nutrients.  While possible biologic pathways can be envisioned, this hypothesis is largely speculative.
column103: The transformation of the placenta from a homogeneous chorionic sac to a placental disc (chorion frondosum) and membranes (chorion laevae) occurs at around 8-10 weeks gestation.  Absence of extravillous trophoblastic plugs at the lateral margin of the placenta is believed to increase oxygen tension triggering villous involution and membrane formation.  A global reduction in endometrial blood flow could interfere with this process and some evidence suggests that placenta membranacea may be associated with endometrial chronic inflammation, mechanical injury, abnormal vascularization, and/or hypoplasia.  Placenta membranacea is normally found in some lower primates.
column104: Deviations from normal may lead to absent or reduced fetal blood flow between fetus and placenta.  Consequences include elevated placental venous pressure, reduced fetal oxygenation, fetal hemorrhage, or arteriovenous shunts.
column105: Umbilical cord length is primarily determined by stretching or lack thereof reflecting variations in fetal movement and/or restrictive entanglements
column106: Long umbilical cord is thought to reflect increased fetal movement leading to stretch-related remodeling.  Umbilical cord entanglements may also augment stretching and are another associated factor.  Consequences and complications of long umbilical cord include entanglement (e.g. nuchal or body cords), increased resistance owing to length alone (increased length causes increased resistance and decreased flow by Pouiselle’s law), and predisposition to excessive coiling and true knot formation, all of which can compromise fetoplacental perfusion.
column107: Short umbilical cord generally reflects decreased fetal movement.  Causes can be separated into intrinsic or extrinsic categories.  The intrinsic group includes CNS and muscular anomalies, limb deficiencies, and urinary tract malformations associated with oligohydramnios.  The extrinsic group includes other causes of oligohydramnios, restrictive endometrial environment (e.g. bicornuate uterus of submucosal leiomyoma), and amniotic bands that tether the fetus to the placenta.  The most extreme example of the latter is early amnion rupture sequence which is occasionally associated with umbilical cord agenesis.
column108: Thin umbilical cords are generally due to decreased amount and hydration of extracellular matrix (Wharton’s jelly).  Excessive twisting (hypercoiled umbilical cord) is incompletely understood and may either be a primary or secondary abnormality.  Hypercoiling or localized compression can lead to strictures.  Hypocoiled umbilical cord and thick umbilical cord (>2 cm diameter) are less well understood, but may also be associated with adverse outcomes.
column109: Thin umbilical cords are generally due to a decreased amount and hydration of extracellular matrix (Wharton’s jelly) secondary to maternal vascular malperfusion and other causes of uteroplacental insufficiency.  Thick umbilical cord (>2 cm diameter), due to increased Wharton’s jelly, is less well understood but may also be associated with adverse outcomes
column110: Most umbilical cords have an irreducible twist, fixed by the spiraling of the umbilical arteries around the vein.  This twist appears to be determined early in pregnancy and clockwise or left twisting is more common than right by a 7:1 ratio.  The underlying basis for the initiation, magnitude, and directionality of coiling is unclear, but data suggests that hypercoiled umbilical cords are more commonly right-twisted and that hypercoiled umbilical cords with a right twist are at higher risk for an adverse outcome than those with a left twist.  Adverse outcomes are largely restricted to hypercoiled umbilical cords with indentations.  Hypocoiled umbilical cord (one or fewer diagonal grooves/ 10cm) is less well understood, but may also be associated with adverse outcomes.
column111: Strictures can be seen alone or combined with hypercoiling and cord indentations.  Animal studies have shown that transient cord compression in early pregnancy can also lead to stricture formation.  The most common site of stricture is at the fetal umbilicus, a finding that may be related to physiologic constriction near the umbilical ring after 20 weeks.
column112: Theories explaining non-paracentral UC insertion overlap with those for abnormal placental shape.  Both processes appear to be largely determined early in pregnancy.  UC insertion is generally believed to be paracentral at the time of implantation.  Asymmetric development of placental parenchyma relative to the umbilical cord insertion site may be caused by preferential development in areas with better blood supply (“trophotropism”) or skewed chorionic surface vascular patterning during fetoplacental vasculogenesis.
column113: Umbilical cord insertion is generally believed to be paracentral at the time of implantation.  Asymmetric development of placental parenchyma relative to the original insertion site due to either preferential development in areas with better blood supply (“trophotropism”) or skewed chorionic surface vascular patterning results in cord insertion in the membranous chorionic laevae at delivery.
column114: Umbilical cord insertion is generally believed to be paracentral at the time of implantation.  Asymmetric development of placental parenchyma relative to the original insertion site due to either preferential development in areas with better blood supply (“trophotropism”) or skewed chorionic surface vascular patterning results in cord insertion at the margin of the placental disc at delivery.  Marginal insertion may be associated with a magistral or monopodal chorionic vessel branching pattern (perpendicular branching off a major trunk).
column115: Umbilical cord insertion is generally believed to be paracentral at the time of implantation.  Asymmetric development of placental parenchyma relative to the original insertion site due to either preferential development in areas with better blood supply (“trophotropism”) or skewed chorionic surface vascular patterning results in cord insertion close to the margin of the placental disc at delivery.  Peripheral insertion may be associated with a magistral or monopodal chorionic vessel branching pattern (perpendicular branching off a major trunk).
column116: Pathogenesis is unknown, but unprotected vessels are susceptible to tearing or torsion with fetal movement or during parturition.
column117: Pathogenesis is unknown, but fetal blood flow can be restricted if the umbilical cord is pulled in a direction opposite to that of the tethering fold of amnion.
column118: Deoxygenated blood from the fetus is normally transmitted to the placenta via paired umbilical arteries that enter the cord at the umbilicus.  These arteries spiral around the umbilical vein and normally communicate with one another via the Hyrtl anastomosis, located within 3 cm of the cord insertion site into the placenta. Oxygenated blood from the placenta normally travels in a single (left) umbilical vein which drains to the ductus venosus and the fetal right atrium.  One umbilical artery may be lost or the second may never develop.  Umbilical veins are initially paired in the fetus and a persistent right umbilical vein can sometimes enter the umbilical cord.  Persistent small paired vitelline arteries initially accompany the omphalomesenteric duct through the placenta to the yolk sac.  All of these umbilical vessels may be damaged or form proliferative tumor-like lesions that are occasionally associated with a large adjacent pseudocyst.
