column119: Two theories: (1) primary failure of the vasculogenic mesenchyme flanking the allantoic duct to form two functional arteries and (2) secondary involution of an initially normal second artery.  The common association with membranous umbilical cord insertion suggests that mechanical factors might lead to obliteration of one artery, favoring the second theory.  Rare type II single umbilical arteries are true malformations associated with caudal maldevelopment (e.g. acardiac twin, sirenomelia, caudal regression syndrome)
column120: The single (left) umbilical cord vein normally joins paired intraembryonic umbilical veins just caudal to the fetal umbilicus.  The pre-hepatic portion of the right umbilical vein normally disappears at around 6 weeks gestation, but persistent flow in the umbilical cord may forestall involution.
column121: Venous aneurysms are more common and typically occur in areas of extreme varicosity (large “false knots”).  They may be caused by sudden increases in tension with fetal cord entanglements.  Arterial aneurysms are associated with chromosomal abnormalities, particularly trisomy 18, and may follow thrombosis and medial degeneration.
column122: Fetoplacental vessels have the capacity to undergo adventitial angiogenesis during development and this can be recapitulated in pathologic situations (e.g. prolonged bacterial infection).  Angiomyxomas most likely represent expansion of such foci into tumor-like masses.  Adjacent cyst formation is probably caused by transudation of fluid from the vascular component.  Whether they are reactive proliferations, malformations, or clonal neoplasms is not known.
column123: These vascular malformative lesions are most likely related to abnormal development in regions near the branch points of umbilical and major chorionic vessels.
column124: Vitelline vessels accompanying the omphalomesenteric duct in the umbilical cord may persist through part or all of the umbilical cord.  Benign vascular proliferations can arise where they terminate before reaching the yolk sac.
column125: Cysts confined to the UC are detected in 2-3% of first trimester ultrasounds, but are rare in later pregnancy.  They can form by obstructed outflow from epithelial ducts, surface invagination, or localized edema.
column126: The allantoic duct is the extraembryonic extension of the urachus and provides a scaffolding for the placental chorioallantoic circulation.
column127: The omphalomesenteric (vitelline) duct connects the fetal intestinal tract to the yolk sac and is accompanied by small vitelline vessels that normally involute in early pregnancy.
column128: Invagination of umbilical surface epithelium (which is embryologically related to amnion and fetal skin).
column129: Isolated pseudocysts represent exaggerations of commonly encountered foci of liquefaction within Wharton’s jelly and are increased with aneuploidy, particularly Trisomy 18.  Pseudocysts associated with angiomyxoma probably reflect transudation of fluid from the adjacent vascular lesion.
column130: Origin is uncertain.  Hypotheses include displaced yolk sac elements (choristoma), ectopic embryonic tissues (heterotopias), or a monodermal teratoma.  Origin from displaced pluripotent stem cells is possible.
column131: Origin is uncertain.  Hypotheses include ectopic migration of coelomic mesenchymal cells, embolic spread of adrenal progenitor cells, and origin from pluripotent embryonic or multi-potential placental stem cells.
column132: Origin is uncertain.  Hypotheses include displaced yolk sac elements with hepatic differentiation (choristoma), ectopic embryonic liver (heterotopia) lacking portal structures, or a monodermal teratoma containing entirely hepatoid elements.  Origin from displaced pluripotent stem cells is possible.
column133: Tumors arising from primitive villous trophoblastic precursors or germ cells in the yolk sac.  Remnants of an unrecognized acardiac or other resorbing twin gestation must be excluded.
column134: Teratomas develop from primordial germ cells that arise in the dorsal wall of the yolk sac and are displaced from their normal migratory path to the fetal genital ridge.  Placental localization could occur by contiguous extension from the yolk sac or retrograde migration back through the body stalk (umbilical cord) from the primitive gut.
column135: Only two cases reported, one associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.  Neither metastasized to mother or infant.  Possible origins include primitive germ cells within the yolk sac or pluripotential stem cells.
column136: Gestational choriocarcinomas usually arise from preceding diandric complete hydatidiform moles.  Intraplacental tumors that develop within apparently normal placentas may reflect androgenetic/ biparental mosaicism or have a distinct pathogenesis.
column137: Myometrial contractions, toxic exposures, and direct physical force can lead to cervical dilatation, premature rupture of the membranes, laceration of fetal vessels in the membranes or umbilical cord, and damage to fetal vessels and their supporting structures in the umbilical cord and chorionic plate.
column138: Myometrial contractions, bacterial infections, and direct physical force contribute to premature cervical dilatation and/or rupture of the amnion, chorion, or both.
column139: Longstanding decreases in amniotic fluid volume (oligohydramnios) cause fetal skin cells to become adherent to and incorporated within the amniotic epithelium, most likely due to amniocyte damage caused by increased contact between fetus and placenta and/or hyperconcentration of amniotic fluid.
column140: The most widely accepted hypothesis is that early rupture of the amnion causes fibrous bands to form inside the remaining intact chorion which then encircle fetal structures or the umbilical cord.  Alternative suggestions suggest an underlying abnormality in the amnion and/or affected fetal parts (Streeter hypothesis).
column141: Either late amnion rupture or late amniochorionic separation followed by amnion rupture.
column142: Large fetal vessels can be torn secondary to uterine instrumentation (amniocentesis, pressure catheters), tension (complete or partial avulsion of umbilical cord), or by laceration upon membrane rupture when vessels overly the cervical os (ruptured vasa previa).  In some cases, the ruptured vessels have preexisting defects caused by prolonged meconium exposure, pressure-related necrosis, or vascular thrombi.
column143: Fetal gastric acid and bile-containing stool contents can enter the amniotic fluid due to upper gastrointestinal tract obstruction and antenatal defecation (meconium release), respectively.  These agents can cause tissue damage and dysfunction with prolonged exposure. Toxicity may be amplified by hyperconcentration with oligohydramnios, but this is less well established.
column144: Transient fetal hypoxia in mature fetuses leads to redistribution of blood flow away from fetal gut (“diving reflex”) resulting in defecation (meconium release).  Meconium contains bile acids, phospholipases, and other toxic stool components that can cause tissue necrosis or apoptosis.
column145: Remote or repetitive episodes of fetal defecation in response to hypoxia leads to meconium release without subsequent delivery.  Prolonged exposure in the absence of membrane rupture, especially with oligohydramnios, allows for progressive diffusion of toxic agents deep into the umbilical cord and chorionic plate causing vasospasm, vascular injury, and tissue necrosis.
column146: Two etiologies: extremely prolonged amniotic fluid meconium exposure and fetal gastrointestinal tract obstruction leading to reflux of gastric acid into the amniotic fluid.
column147: Genomic disorders lead to altered gene expression that may result in abnormal placental structure and function
column148: Genomic structural abnormalities lead to changes in gene expression that can result in abnormal placental structure and function
column149: Chromosomal abnormalities affecting both fetus and placenta lead to changes in gene expression that can result in abnormal placental structure and function

column151: Single gene defects affecting both fetus and placenta lead to changes in gene expression that can result in abnormal placental structure and function
column152: Genomic disorders secondary to variations in parental DNA dosage lead to changes in gene expression attributable to differential imprinting that result in abnormal placental structure and function
column153: Increased levels of critical paternally-expressed gene products promote trophoblast proliferation.  Decreased levels of maternally-expressed gene products lead to truncated abnormal placental fetal stromal vascular development.  Usually caused by fertilization of an empty oocyte (lacking a maternally-derived pronucleus); monospermy with endoduplication or dispermy.  A rare, maternally heritable autosomal dominant trait associated with recurrent molar pregnancy is caused by an NLRP7 gene imprinting mutation, located on chromosome 19q13 that leads to over-expression of paternally-expressed transcripts.
column154: Abnormal initial division of the fertilized egg in which the female genome fails to duplicate leaving one normal biparental daughter cell and the other containing only paternally-derived chromosomes.  Since YY androgenetic cells are nonviable, all cases are female.  Extent of placental involvement depends on the relative viability and function of the androgenetic clone which is usually restricted to villous mesenchyme (stroma and vessels).  Rare cases may show foci with androgenetic trophoblast (complete hydatidiform mole).
column155: Syndrome characterized by abnormal expression of maternally and paternally imprinted genes at the chromosome 11p15.2 locus due to internal mutations, deletions, duplications, or partial uniparental disomy affecting specific genes in the 11p15.2 region and their imprinting control regions (IC1 and IC2).  IC2 abnormalities are associated with placental mesenchymal dysplasia; IC1 abnormalities with other pathologic findings including perivillous fibrin with trophoblast atypia.
column156: Trisomic pregnancy, usually secondary to meiotic nondisjunction, with loss of the unaffected chromosome resulting in euploidy with uniparental origin for the two remaining chromosomes.  Dysregulation of parentally imprinted genes can lead to fetal malformations or growth restriction.
column157: DNA alterations including, but not restricted to, promoter methylation and histone modification that affect gene expression but do not alter the genomic sequence.
